conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the motion of cargo A on a conveyor belt with adjustable length, speed, and height. The conveyor moves clockwise at a speed of 2 m/s, and the length of the conveyor is 6 m. The kinetic friction coefficient between the cargo and the conveyor is 0.2. Cargo A is released from rest at the left end of the conveyor.
Figure C shows a horizontal conveyor belt with cargo A placed at the left end. The conveyor moves clockwise, and the length of the conveyor is labeled as L1.

premise: The cargo is released from rest, and the conveyor moves at 2 m/s. The kinetic friction coefficient is 0.2.
conclusion: The acceleration of cargo A can be calculated using Newton's second law: \( f_1 = m a_1 \) and \( f_1 = \mu N_1 \), where \( N_1 = m g \). Substituting values gives \( a_1 = \mu g = 0.2 \times 10 = 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).

premise: The acceleration of cargo A is \( a_1 = 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), and the conveyor speed is \( v_0 = 2 \, \text{m/s} \).
conclusion: Using the kinematic formula \( v_0 = a_1 t_1 \), the time taken for cargo A to reach the same speed as the conveyor is \( t_1 = v_0 / a_1 = 2 / 2 = 1 \, \text{s} \).

premise: The acceleration of cargo A is \( a_1 = 2 \, \text{m/s}^2 \), and the time to reach the conveyor speed is \( t_1 = 1 \, \text{s} \).
conclusion: Using the kinematic formula \( v_0^2 = 2 a_1 s_1 \), the distance traveled by cargo A to reach the conveyor speed is \( s_1 = v_0^2 / (2 a_1) = 2^2 / (2 \times 2) = 1 \, \text{m} \).

premise: The total length of the conveyor is \( L_1 = 6 \, \text{m} \), and the distance traveled to reach the conveyor speed is \( s_1 = 1 \, \text{m} \).
conclusion: The remaining distance for cargo A to travel at constant velocity is \( L_1 - s_1 = 6 - 1 = 5 \, \text{m} \).

premise: The remaining distance is \( 5 \, \text{m} \), and the conveyor speed is \( v_0 = 2 \, \text{m/s} \).
conclusion: The time taken to travel the remaining distance at constant velocity is \( t_2 = (L_1 - s_1) / v_0 = 5 / 2 = 2.5 \, \text{s} \).
